content:
Meeting 2022-01-11T17:00:00+01:00 (T-1h)

Agenda:

  • Implement framework so that lints can be enabled in nightly only clippy#8211
  • ...?
:wave:
:wave:
:wave:
:wave:

So, I guess I'll start to talk about clippy#8211. The idea is to implement a framework that allows us to only enable lints on nightly to ensure that lints on stable are tested better than they currently are. Ideally, this could also be expanded to behavior changes.

I think the main open question is: what should happen in stable with #[warn(some_unstable_lint)].

  1. Enable the lint
  2. Error "this lint is only available in nightly"

I've done some testing with implementing a custom suppression mechanism but got stuck on some logic.

The added complexity would in my opinion not be worth the effort. So I'm leaning towards just having the lints as allow-by-default on stable as suggested in the issue.
Correct @Cameron Steffen
I would not error, but perhaps warn that this lint is deemed unstable. But if that's too much complexity, documenting it will be fine.
maybe ignore it by default and have some magic flag similar to RUST_BOOTSTRAP to enable it anyway (on your own risk etc)?
A warn attribute is also deliberate, I think it's fine to enable it in that case as usual
I think ignoring it with no feedback would be bad
@matthiaskrgr wouldn't an "unstable" lint group do that exact same thing (with the -W clippy::unstable command line arg)?
Having an extra environment value to enable the nightly behavior was also suggested in "t-compiler/help" when I asked about something related

llogiq said:

matthiaskrgr wouldn't an "unstable" lint group do that exact same thing (with the -W clippy::unstable command line arg)?

A clippy::unstable group could be problematic when we have new restriction lints as users would probably not want to enable them even if they want to test unstable lints
(joining the meeting, sorry for beeing late)
What if #[warn(unstable_lint)] triggers another lint - clippy::unstable_lints?
I think there was talk about unstable rustc lints before and how to handle those
lintception
we have to lint deeper...

What if #[warn(unstable_lint)] triggers another lint - clippy::unstable_lints?

Similar to how our restriction lint group works?

that other lint would just be the mechanism for:
llogiq said:

I would not error, but perhaps warn that this lint is deemed unstable.
That could work, but then I don't see a benefit of having a group at all. Lints don't have to be in a group AFAIK :thinking:

Similar to how our restriction lint group works?

I'm not sure
The idea of an "unstable" group is to be able to select them quickly for testing.
This Rust PR might also be interesting for this discussion: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/72970
So unstable would become a stepping stone between nursery and all?

This Rust PR might also be interesting for this discussion: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/72970

The thing is if we want the lints to be available in stable, that is different from rustc feature gates, which completely block things on stable.
so the question is how "official" or "inofficial" enabling them on stable should be?
Right.. The question is if we want them available on stable. I don't really want them available on stable, or rather a no-op lint
I don't see a big benefit of making a lint unavailable on stable.

llogiq said:

So unstable would become a stepping stone between nursery and all?

Yes, it would stand for lints, which we consider to be ready but don't want to have them warn in case we missed something or the community disagrees
As long as we document that a lint is unstable and give sufficient warning to potential users, what's the harm?
As long as they do not trigger on stable by default, there shouldn't be any harm
They could still have some ICEs in them but I don't think that there is an efficient way to avoid this
On nightly I don't want those lints to be only available in the clippy::unstable group, but rather directly in the group where they belong
We can add an extra is_nightly() check to the implementations similar to how is_lint_allowed() works

I initially thought this should work like rustc features, but then I realized we don't really have the capacity to add actual rustc features, so then I don't think there is a need to be consistent (error if the lint is used at all).
Hm, but if you forget that during impl/review, the lint would get directly into stable
Why do we need is_nightly() check?

flip1995 said:

Hm, but if you forget that during impl/review, the lint would get directly into stable

No that would be an additional check that could be done to avoid ICEs in the code until the emission
Sorry if that was not clear :sweat_smile:
Maybe add the nightly lints to the group where they belong AND to a new (hidden) clippy::unstable group and suppress the lint if it is in the unsable group AND toolchain!=nighlty

Cameron Steffen said:

I think the main open question is: what should happen in stable with #[warn(some_unstable_lint)]?

  1. Enable the lint
  2. Error "this lint is only available in nightly"

I would like to decide on this first otherwise I am confused. Are we choosing option 1?
I would say we don't error.
But also, that we don't necessarily enable the lint on stable, if that's too hard to implement

Cameron Steffen said:

I think ignoring it with no feedback would be bad
Ah I missed that

flip1995 said:

Maybe add the nightly lints to the group where they belong AND to a new (hidden) clippy::unstable group and suppress the lint if it is in the unsable group AND toolchain!=nighlty

I think it would be easier to only register the lints in their lint group if nightly features (Or an environment value is set) are enabled. That would just require a small adjustment to clippy_dev update_lints and rustc would to the heavy lifting for us. I want to create one or two prototypes, and this is an idea to look into. It might actually solve one of my problems xD
Could we have an alternative register_unstable if nightly features aren't enabled? That way we'd get a better message than "unknown lint"?
Is there a way to do something like cfg_attr(toolchain=nightly, warn(some_unstable_lint))?

Could we have an alternative register_unstable if nightly features aren't enabled? That way we'd get a better message than "unknown lint"?

If the lint is usable on stable, there is no need.

Is there a way to do something like cfg_attr(toolchain=nightly, warn(some_unstable_lint))?

I'm pretty sure that is intentionally not possible

flip1995 said:

Is there a way to do something like cfg_attr(toolchain=nightly, warn(some_unstable_lint))?

I don't think so. At least I couldn't find such an option

Cameron Steffen said:

Is there a way to do something like cfg_attr(toolchain=nightly, warn(some_unstable_lint))?

I'm pretty sure that is intentionally not possible

Yeah, then warning/erroring on #[warn(some_unstable_lint)] is not a good idea, because user that use both toolchains won't have a way to control a lint without erroring on stable.
You mean a "this lint is not available" warning/error is a bad idea?
yeah
I think a "this lint is unstable" warning would be okay. Note that any use of #![feature(...)] on stable errors.
But also the "unstable lint" warning may as well fire on unstable too.
And if it is a lint, you can do #![allow(clippy::unstable_lints)]

Yeah, but if we want users to test the nightly lints on CI (users that run stable + nightly toolchains on CI) we don't want to break their CI, because the lint fires on nightly, but can't be disabled, beccause that would break the stable CI build
That's why I'd say just ignoring those unstable lint attributes on stable might not be such a bad idea
If #[warn(unstable_lint)] breaks the build, then it would break on stable and nightly right?
But I think you have a point that enabling lints by default on nighly could cause problems.
We could have a config enable_unstable_lints: false (edit: nvm the lint group is enough)
We could also add a console argument to clippy
I don't really want to teach Clippy users flags or config options, so that they can test our new unstable lints for us.
It can be on be default in nightly still. The config would be for turning it off.
So unstable lints would be enabled also on stable, except if the config option is set?
off by default in stable
Having an opt out for nightly sounds like a good idea to me :upside_down:
Yeah, but that doesn't really solve the problem with #[warn(some_unstable_lint)], or what am I missing?
Actually all we need is a lint group! !#[allow(clippy::unstable]
I don't think I understand the problem

So we want to enable the lints on nightly by default and suppress them on stable.

If a lint now wrongly triggers on nightly, the user has to be able to allow this lint.

If that allow(unstable_lint) would error on stable (and possibly on nightly), then we would break the stable build and make it impossible for the user to allow unstable lints.
So I would suggest to not warn/error on those on stable
They could add #![allow(clippy::unstable_lints)]. Or we could set it so clippy::unstable_lints doesn't fire for allow.

Cameron Steffen said:

Or we could set it so clippy::unstable_lints doesn't fire for allow.

Then unstable lints in restriction/pedantic could never be enabled on nightly without the allow attribute

Cameron Steffen said:

They could add #![allow(clippy::unstable_lints)].

Wouldn't you always add that to your crate if you want to build it for both nightly and stable?

Wouldn't you always add that to your crate if you want to build it for both nightly and stable?

I think so. It's like feature(..).
Hmm, that's a good point
I think I can settle for this option :smiley:
I think there's a fair chance people building for both wouldn't just disable them, unless the nightly only lints were particularly disruptive

flip1995 said:

I think I can settle for this option :smiley:

Could someone summarize what the option is, I got lost? :sweat_smile:

Alex Macleod said:

I think there's a fair chance people building for both wouldn't just disable them, unless the nightly only lints were particularly disruptive

Yeah, I'm talking about FPs in those unstable lints, which can only be fixed by adding an allow

Could someone summarize what the option is, I got lost? :sweat_smile:

Changing the lint level for an unstable lint triggers clippy::unstable_lints. That lint in turn can be allowed on the crate.

flip1995 said:

Alex Macleod said:

I think there's a fair chance people building for both wouldn't just disable them, unless the nightly only lints were particularly disruptive

Yeah, I'm talking about FPs in those unstable lints, which can only be fixed by adding an allow

If think for FPs the expect attribute is the best solution, and that's WIP
Or better say waiting on review

xFrednet said:

flip1995 said:

Alex Macleod said:

I think there's a fair chance people building for both wouldn't just disable them, unless the nightly only lints were particularly disruptive

Yeah, I'm talking about FPs in those unstable lints, which can only be fixed by adding an allow

If think for FPs the expect attribute is the best solution, and that's WIP

Yes, but users must have some way to suppress unstable lints. with FPs
So do we have anything else to discuss on this topic? @triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.

I'm not entirely convinced clippy::unstable_lints is actually necessary though. I would be okay with just allowing the lint to be used in stable without warning. It's up to the user to know that it's unstable. They should know since they should find the lint in the docs anyways.

Cameron Steffen said:

I'm not entirely convinced clippy::unstable_lints is actually necessary though. I would be okay with just allowing the lint to be used in stable without warning. It's up to the user to know that it's unstable. They should know since they should find the lint in the docs anyways.

Yep, I would also be fine with that. I'm just afraid that it will be really hard to implement to disable unstable lints by default on stable but at the same time take outer warn attributes into account.
But if that is possible to implement, I think this is a good solution
I think it is, I'll look into it :upside_down:
Perfect, thanks for all the work on this @xFrednet !
I think we can end the meeting now @triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
FYI: I'm now back from vacation and have a bit more time this month for Clippy, so I'll go through all my notification and reviews in the next few days :)
Thanks for attending everyone! :wave:

A small heads up (And now related to the previous discussion). I'm currently working on my bachelor thesis, which sadly takes up most of my time. I'll probably be less active in the next couple of weeks until I have to hand it in February. So I'll start to look into that once I have more time again :sweat_smile:
I'm also considering removing myself from the rotation of highfive bot for the mean time. (I would love to continue reviewing and hacking on Clippy again once my schedule cleared up :upside_down: ).
Sure, if Clippy work is too overwhelming, just submit a PR to the highfive repo :+1:
It's more a loved distraction xD

I'm just afraid that it will be really hard to implement to disable unstable lints by default on stable but at the same time take outer warn attributes into account.

I think that's easy as just add the lint to its respective warn-by-default category on nightly only.
Oh yeah, I had the highest rate of Clippy contributions during the end of my master thesis :smiley:
